qas.question: What is the active component of the U.S. Army?
What are the two reserve components of the U.S. Army?

answers.text: Army National Guard and the Army Reserve

qas.question: The U.S. Army is organized under what title of the United States Code?
Who does the D.C. National Guard report to?
What is the inactive component of the U.S. Army?

plausible_answers.text: Army National Guard and the Army Reserve

qas.question: What are the two reserve components of the U.S. Navy?
The U.S. Army is organized under what title of the United Nations Code?
Who does the D.C. National Navy report to?

context: The United States Army is made up of three components: the active component, the <a0_0><b5_0>Regular Army<b5_0/><a0_0/>; and two reserve components, the <a1_0><b6_0>Army National Guard and the Army Reserve<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Both reserve components are primarily composed of part-time soldiers who train once a month, known as battle assemblies or <a2_0>unit training assemblies<a2_0/> (UTAs), and conduct two to three weeks of annual training each year. Both the Regular Army and the Army Reserve are organized under Title <a3_0><b7_0>10<b7_0/><a3_0/> of the United States Code, while the National Guard is organized under Title 32. While the Army National Guard is organized, trained and equipped as a component of the U.S. Army, when it is not in federal service it is under the command of individual state and territorial governors; the District of Columbia National Guard, however, reports to <a4_0>the <b8_0>U.S. President<b8_0/><a4_0/>, not the district's mayor, even when not federalized. Any or all of the National Guard can be federalized by presidential order and against the governor's wishes.
